instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that doesn't recognize the SSD.

Already tried several other SSD with the same result. Does this model use to have the CPU problem? How can I test it?

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
threads.message:
Any history available?
Check <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> voltages, w/ and w/o SSD connected.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
threads.message:
Hi,
No history. Client says that it stoped working.

<CHIP>U3740</CHIP>  with SSD connected:
1 = 3.4V
2 = 0.998V
3 = 3.287V
4= 0V
6= 0.633V
7= 0V
8= 3.284V

<CHIP>U3740</CHIP>  w/o SSD connected:
1 = 3.4V
2 = 1V
3 = 3.287V
4= 0V
6= 0.627V
7= 3.3V
8= 3.284V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R1620</RESISTOR>/96; only one must be used.
You can try to force the power enable soldering a lower value.
Use <RESISTOR>R8070</RESISTOR>, as last resort...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
threads.message:
Hi,

After all, it seams that I still have a problem with it.
When instaling the macos, when it reaches 1 minute for complete the installation, it stays there forever...
Already tried 2 SSDs
Any idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
threads.message:
Hi,
Yes, already tried a clean ME

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
threads.message: Test with an SSD with macOS preinstalled on other machine.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
threads.message:
Hi,
 
Now everything works. However the fan is always at full RPM, and the videos (YouTube, etc.) are very laggy. 
Already tried new trackpad and cable, but with same result.
Can it be related with the fact that I've used <RESISTOR>R8070</RESISTOR> to get the enable signal?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no disk
threads.message:
Shouldn't be related.
Run HWMonitor and see if any temp, or current sensor looks strange.
